title: Emsley Carr Mile
text:
The Emsley Carr Mile is an annual invitational <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a> <a href="running">running</a> event held in the United Kingdom over <a href="mile%20run">one mile</a> for men. The race has been part of the <a href="London%20Grand%20Prix">London Grand Prix</a> since 2008, and was won in 2019 by the <a href="Ethiopia">Ethiopian</a> athlete <a href="Samuel%20Tefera">Samuel Tefera</a>.
History.
The race was inaugurated in 1953 by Sir William Carr in memory of his father <a href="Emsley%20Carr">Sir Emsley Carr</a>, a former editor of the "<a href="News%20of%20the%20World">News of the World</a>". The event was created to encourage athletes to break the <a href="four-minute%20mile">four-minute mile</a>. By the second time the race was run, <a href="Roger%20Bannister">Roger Bannister</a> had already broken the <a href="List%20of%20world%20records%20in%20athletics">world record</a> on 6 May 1954 at the annual athletics event between the <a href="Amateur%20Athletics%20Association">Amateur Athletics Association</a> (AAA) and <a href="Oxford%20University">Oxford University</a> at the <a href="Roger%20Bannister%20running%20track">Iffley Road Track</a> in <a href="Oxford">Oxford</a>. Bannister never did run in the Emsley Carr Mile.
The winners of the race sign the Emsley Carr Trophy, a red Moroccan leather-bound book, now running into a second volume since 1980.
It contains a history of mile running since 1868 from around the world and also includes signatures of many of the world's leading milers, including <a href="Paavo%20Nurmi">Paavo Nurmi</a>, <a href="Sydney%20Wooderson">Sydney Wooderson</a>, <a href="John%20Landy">John Landy</a>, <a href="Gordon%20Pirie">Gordon Pirie</a>, and Roger Bannister. The race has been won by eleven Olympic champions, <a href="Kipchoge%20Keino">Kip Keino</a>, <a href="Steve%20Ovett">Steve Ovett</a>, <a href="Murray%20Halberg">Murray Halberg</a>, <a href="John%20Walker%20%28athlete%29">John Walker</a>, <a href="Sebastian%20Coe">Sebastian Coe</a>, <a href="Sa%C3%AFd%20Aouita">Saïd Aouita</a>, <a href="William%20Tanui">William Tanui</a>, <a href="V%C3%A9nuste%20Niyongabo">Vénuste Niyongabo</a>, <a href="Haile%20Gebrselassie">Haile Gebrselassie</a>, <a href="Asbel%20Kiprop">Asbel Kiprop</a>, and <a href="Hicham%20El%20Guerrouj">Hicham El Guerrouj</a>. It has also been won by seven athletes who have held the world record for the mile: Walker, Ovett, Coe, El Guerrouj, <a href="Filbert%20Bayi">Filbert Bayi</a>, <a href="Derek%20Ibbotson">Derek Ibbotson</a> and <a href="Jim%20Ryun">Jim Ryun</a>.
<a href="Ken%20Wood%20%28athlete%29">Ken Wood</a>, a former Sheffield athlete, won the Emsley Carr Mile a record four times. The fastest time recorded for the event stands at 3:45.96 by El Guerrouj in 2000. It is the ninth fastest time ever recorded for the mile, and the fastest time recorded on British soil. El Guerrouj won the Emsley Carr Mile in 2000, 2001 and 2002. 
In 1969 Sir William Carr decided not to continue sponsoring the race and the AAA took it over and continued until he died in 1977. Since 1977, Emsley Carr's grandson, William, has continued with the tradition and has kept the book up to date and has provided a glass piece, presented to the winner by a member of the Carr family.
